article_title: Patrick Roy is OK with Gabe Landeskog’s C – The Denver Post
article_text:
Gabe Landeskog, who turned 22 on Nov. 23, is in his third season as the Avalanche’s captain. A bit of perspective: Ten players on the University of Denver Pioneers’ roster are older than the Avalanche’s captain.

Of late, Avalanche coach Patrick Roy has made it a habit of referring to Landeskog not by name, but as: “Our captain …”

“He deserves it,” Roy said Thursday in Vancouver. “The way he’s been acting on and off the ice, he’s been showing great leadership, and to me, this is very positive.”

As a locker room spokesman for the team once the media hordes invade, Landeskog is thoughtful and eloquent — if not particularly controversial — to the point that many hearing him or even asking the questions often forget he is a native Swede, speaking in his second language. It’s almost as if you want to dare him to say something in Swedish to prove he’s not a guy from Saskatoon pulling a fast one.

When the Avalanche named him captain in September 2012, it came off as a bit theatrical, at least in terms of the timing. The NHL was in the early stages of a lockout that would last until January. But naming Landeskog captain then meant, at age 19, he became the youngest with the C in NHL history, beating Pittsburgh’s Sidney Crosby by 11 days.

Avs Mailbag: Pose a question for Terry Frei, Mike Chambers

That led into the final season of the Joe Sacco coaching tenure at Colorado, a mess that led to the housecleaning that included Roy’s return to the franchise. Yes, there were moments when it seemed that Roy pondered saying that Landes- kog wasn’t ready for the C, that it was unnecessary additional pressure for a young player, and made another choice. But Roy says those who drew those inferences were wrong.

“I guess the fact that I’ve been working with younger players at the junior level helped me a lot, and my objective was to try and help him as much as I could,” Roy said. “At the same time, I think Landy’s been the choice of the organization and I have no problem with that. Actually, right now I’m very pleased with the step he has made in his role as the captain of the team.”

This is legitimizing too: Going into Saturday’s home game against Buffalo, Landeskog had 12 goals in the previous 20 games as the Avalanche at least showed signs of avoiding an ignominious folding down the stretch of a disappointing season. He took over the team scoring lead, and came into the night with 22 goals and 54 points.

The Landeskog-Ryan O’Reilly-Alex Tanguay line has been terrific of late. And Landeskog seems to have grown into the captain’s role.

“I think no doubt, when the team’s going through a tough time, that’s when you get a challenge as a captain and as a player,” Landeskog said. “You get challenged both as an individual and as a team. When I first got the C, every loss became so much more personal, and that’s something that’s definitely been hard on everybody this year, especially at the start of the year.

“As the season has progressed, I feel like I’ve been able to focus on seeing the outside picture and seeing what the team is looking like, and being able to assess and address the team accordingly, and being able to lead in the way I want to lead. If I’m not focused on what I have to do out there on the ice, I’m not going to play my game, and if I don’t play my game, I’m not going to lead the team. It’s been both up and down, but I feel like I’ve definitely come a little way on the journey.”

Landeskog’s torrid streak of late has enhanced his credibility.

“The last two months, he’s been one of the best players in this league,” Roy said.

Jarome Iginla was the longtime captain at Calgary and now, with Cody McLeod, is an assistant captain with the Avs. In his first season with Colorado, Iginla has gained respect for Landeskog. “He’s one of the top power forwards in the league,” said Iginla, who then rattled off Landeskog’s various on-ice roles before adding of the captain role: “He does a great job because he knows what’s going on with all the guys, and he and Patty have a good relationship. They go in and they talk things out. I’m impressed. I was older when I was captain and there still was pressure and at times I felt it, but you don’t notice it with him. His game has only gotten better and better.”

Terry Frei: tfrei@denverpost.com or twitter.com/TFrei
